Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to develop new controllable tensegrity structures and motion control strategies by leveraging biological discoveries. The new structures will incorporate morphological and modeling innovations prompted by the benefits they bring to tensegrity systems encountered in biology. For example the membrane and intermediate filaments of the cytoskeleton are crucial in achieving structural integrity and morphing shape capabilities as well as sensing, control, and information transmitting functions of living cells. Likewise, internal cellular elements working close to their integrity limits explain why cells can resist extremely large forces. Therefore, membranes and intermediate filaments with sensing and control capabilities will be added to current tensegrity structures and the mathematical modeling assumptions will be relaxed to allow investigation of tensegrity structures close to their mechanical integrity limits. Also many living systems achieve fast and energy efficient motion control using elastic elements for actuation and articulated skeletons that resemble tensegrity structures. Based on the similarities between tensegrity and living structures, this research will develop new motion control strategies that exploit intrinsic properties of tensegrity structures such as prestressability and internal mechanisms. The research objective will be achieved by combining techniques and tools of graph theory, analytical mechanics, structural dynamics, control theory, as well as symbolic and numerical computation.

If successful, the results of this research will answer crucial needs in science and engineering. In biology and medicine they will serve to: a) advance the fundamental understanding of the basic building block of living organisms, the cell; b) comprehend the connection between heart disease and cell?s structure; c) aid tissue and organ reconstruction research; d) explain how nature controls motion is a fast and energy efficient manner. In engineering the mathematical models and control strategies will be critical in validating tensegrity applications such as space telescopes, antennas, robots, thus enabling the jump from feasibility to implementation. In education the integrated research and education program will: a) promote inter- and multi-disciplinary education using tensegrity structures versatility; b) attract children to science using tensegrity structures fascinating appearance and properties; c) enhance the infrastructure for research and education by bringing together researchers from different fields.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to develop novel controllable tensegrity structures and control strategies using inspiration from  biology. The new structures include bars, cables or tendons, and membranes which can be assimilated with the bones, tendons or muscles, and skins or living organisms.

A theory for the mathematical modeling of such structures has been created along with tools and methods for their analysis. Tools for more accurate analysis of membranes or thin structures, exhibiting both large and small amplitude motions, have been generated. Membrane studies revealed the necessity for high dimensional mathematical models for accurate predictions. Feedback control studies revealed the advantages of exploiting the particular mathematical structure of these models to enable modern control for future active membranes. These findings will have broad impact in structural as well as control engineering and will help engineers to better design and analyze thin structures and membranes for numerous applications ranging from adaptive optics to active materials and solar sails.

Novel mathematical models of gradually increasing complexity have been created and validated for tensegrity systems which include membranes. These models revealed the need for an integrated analysis of such systems, due to their high flexibility and strongly coupled behavior. The feasibility of harvesting energy from membranes attached to tensegrity structures using piezoelectric materials has been demonstrated using these models. This finding is significant given the increased interest in renewable energy sources. The broad impact of these models will be felt in architecture and engineering, in the development of future buildings, bridges, retractable roofs, as well as lightweight space systems such as space telescopes, solar sails, antennas, sun shields, energy harvesting devices. In biology/medicine/bio-engineering these models may help advance the understanding of the cell, which can be assimilated with a tensegrity-membrane system. They can help understand the mechanisms through which skeletal biological organisms achieve motion and function and they may be useful in tissue and organ reconstruction research.

Several advanced control methods have been developed, implemented and demonstrated on such systems to achieve stabilization at a desired equilibrium as well as controlled deployment between equilibria. The feasibility of using advanced control in large and complex motions of such sophisticated structural systems was successfully demonstrated. These new findings will impact the development of future autonomous systems such as morphing robots, controlled deployable structures, reconfigurable vehicles.

A theory for stiffness and stability of prestressable structures was created, which can be applied to more general structures than tensegrity. Also a decoupling approximation theory was developed, which can be applied to more general systems than tensegrity structures. Computationally efficient tools associated with both theories have also been developed. The impact of these theoretical and computational advances will be primarily felt in the engineering analysis and design of large systems. Control system design may also be impacted by the decoupling approximation theory, facilitating control design, implementation, and validation for very large systems.

Fast and energy efficient motion control, inspired by the way skeletal biological organisms achieve motions with the same features, was developed and demonstrated for tensegrity systems. Robust feedback  control tools and internal mechanisms, which are intrinsic to tensegrity structures and are also key motion enablers in living skeletal organisms, were used for this purpose. The impact of these advances will be felt in control system development, structural design, and possibly in biology/bioengineering by helping professionals in these fields better understand how nature achieves energy efficient motions.

Tensegrity systems operating in Low Earth Orbits were also studied in this project, resulting in new tools that will impact the design and operation of future space systems operating in close proximity to Earth. For example satellite and deployable antennas design can be directly influenced by these advances.

Broad educational impact was achieved via numerous outreach activities to disseminate the project results such as: presentations at conferences and workshops which targeted a diverse audience; presentations and exhibitions in summer camps which reached segments of the public that are not usually exposed to this kind of research activities such as middle and high school students; seminars and visits at Academic institutions, including research oriented, teaching schools, and diverse Departments, from Engineering to Physics and Mathematics; presentations to industry professionals. The project also led to a spin-off NSF-I Corps teams project aimed at evaluating the commercial readiness of some of the research results. Also project findings have been published in top journals in the field of structures, control, and at the intersection of mechanics, control, signal processing, as well as in top specialized aerospace engineering journals. Some research results helped the PI include new material in courses he teaches. Several students worked on tensegrity research topics during the execution of the project. Most notably, two Ph.D.s have been awarded for research done under this project and a third Ph.D. is expected very soon. Two of the Ph.D. awardees are female students.


Last Modified: 11/29/2016
Modified by: Cornel Sultan
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this project was to develop novel controllable tensegrity structures and control strategies using inspiration from biology. The new structures include bars, cables or tendons, and membranes which can be assimilated with the bones, tendons or muscles, and skins or living organisms. A theory for the mathematical modeling of such structures has been created along with tools and methods for their analysis. Tools for more accurate analysis of membranes or thin structures, exhibiting both large and small amplitude motions, have been generated. Membrane studies revealed the necessity for high dimensional mathematical models for accurate predictions. Novel mathematical models of gradually increasing complexity have been created and validated for tensegrity systems which include membranes. They can help understand the mechanisms through which skeletal biological organisms achieve motion and function and they may be useful in tissue and organ reconstruction research. The feasibility of using advanced control in large and complex motions of such sophisticated structural systems was successfully demonstrated. Some research results helped the PI include new material in courses he teaches. Several students worked on tensegrity research topics during the execution of the project. Most notably, two Ph.D.s have been awarded for research done under this project and a third Ph.D. is expected very soon. Two of the Ph.D. awardees are female students.
